content.title: Asthma Definition and Classification
content.summary: Chronic inflammatory airway disease with variable airflow limitation and bronchial hyperresponsiveness
key_points: Variable symptoms: wheeze, dyspnea, cough, chest tightness
Reversible airflow obstruction (≥12% and 200mL FEV1 improvement with bronchodilator)
ICS is cornerstone of controller therapy
SMART therapy (ICS-formoterol PRN) for mild-moderate asthma

statement.text: Asthma is a heterogeneous disease characterized by chronic airway inflammation with a history of respiratory symptoms (wheeze, shortness of breath, chest tightness, cough) that vary in intensity over time, along with variable expiratory airflow limitation that is often reversible.
statement.formal: Asthma = Variable respiratory symptoms + Variable airflow limitation + Airway hyperresponsiveness + Eosinophilic inflammation

explanation.intuition: Asthma is like having overly sensitive airways that overreact to triggers (allergens, exercise, cold air) by swelling, producing mucus, and squeezing tight. The good news is this bronchoconstriction is usually reversible with treatment.
explanation.key_insight: Unlike COPD, asthma obstruction is variable and reversible. Spirometry shows improvement with bronchodilator (>12% and >200mL FEV1 increase). ICS addresses the underlying inflammation - bronchodilators alone don't treat the cause.

definitions_glossary.asthma: Chronic airway inflammatory disease with variable symptoms and reversible obstruction
definitions_glossary.airway_remodeling: Structural changes from chronic inflammation (wall thickening, smooth muscle hypertrophy)
definitions_glossary.atopy: Genetic tendency to produce IgE in response to allergens
definitions_glossary.LABA: Long-acting beta-agonist - bronchodilator for controller therapy
definitions_glossary.SMART_therapy: Single Maintenance And Reliever Therapy using ICS-formoterol
definitions_glossary.peak_expiratory_flow: PEF - simple measure of airflow; variable in asthma
definitions_glossary.eosinophilic_asthma: Phenotype with elevated blood/sputum eosinophils; responds to ICS

pathophysiology.inflammation: Type 2 inflammation in most: IgE-mediated, eosinophils, Th2 cytokines (IL-4, IL-5, IL-13)
pathophysiology.acute_response: Allergen/trigger → mast cell degranulation → bronchoconstriction (early phase)
pathophysiology.late_response: Eosinophil recruitment → airway edema, mucus (late phase, 4-8h later)
pathophysiology.remodeling: Chronic inflammation → basement membrane thickening, smooth muscle hypertrophy, mucus gland hyperplasia

clinical_history: Variable respiratory symptoms (worse at night/early morning)
Triggered by exercise, allergens, cold air, infections, irritants
History of atopy (eczema, allergic rhinitis, food allergy)
diagnostic_criteria.bronchial_challenge: Methacholine challenge: PC20 <4mg/mL indicates hyperresponsiveness (if spirometry normal)

classification.GINA_severity: Based on treatment needed to control: mild (Step 1-2), moderate (Step 3), severe (Step 4-5)

controller_therapy.Step_1_2: PRN low-dose ICS-formoterol (SMART approach) OR low-dose ICS with SABA PRN
controller_therapy.Step_3: Low-dose ICS-LABA maintenance + PRN SABA or ICS-formoterol SMART
controller_therapy.Step_5: High-dose ICS-LABA + add-on (LAMA, anti-IgE, anti-IL5, anti-IL4/13)

treatment_options.reliever_therapy: PRN ICS-formoterol preferred over SABA alone (reduces severe exacerbations)

biologics.dupilumab: Anti-IL4/13 for eosinophilic or Type 2 asthma

definition.@value: Chronic inflammatory airway disease with variable symptoms, reversible airflow obstruction, and bronchial hyperresponsiveness

learning_objectives: Define asthma and distinguish from COPD
Apply GINA stepwise approach to therapy
Select appropriate biologic therapy based on phenotype
clinical_pearls: ICS-formoterol PRN reduces severe exacerbations vs SABA alone - new standard
Blood eosinophils >300 predict ICS response and biologic eligibility
Never prescribe LABA monotherapy - always with ICS (black box warning)
Methacholine challenge useful when spirometry normal but asthma suspected
Frequent SABA use (>2 canisters/year) = poorly controlled asthma

sources.source: GINA 2024 Report: Global Strategy for Asthma Management and Prevention
